questions.text: Which exception is typically used to detect the end of a file when using `DataInputStream`?
questions.explanation: Unlike `FileInputStream.read()` which returns -1, `DataInputStream` methods throws an `EOFException` when reading past the end of the file.

choices.label: It prints garbage values or throws an exception.
choices.text: It prints garbage values or throws an exception.

questions.explanation: Binary data must be read in the same order/format it was written. The code writes an `int` then a `double`, but attempts to read a `double` first. This will interpret the bytes of the `int` (and part of the `double`) as a `double`, resulting in incorrect data.

questions.text: Which method is used to write a string using UTF-8 encoding scheme in `DataOutputStream`?
questions.explanation: `writeUTF(String s)` writes a string using the UTF coding scheme, which includes the length information needed to read it back.

choices.label: DataInputStream cannot work directly with FileInputStream.
choices.text: DataInputStream cannot work directly with FileInputStream.

choices.label: To convert primitives to strings automatically.
choices.text: To convert primitives to strings automatically.

choices.label: To improve I/O performance by reducing disk reads.
choices.text: To improve I/O performance by reducing disk reads.

questions.explanation: Buffered streams reduce the number of physical disk I/O operations by reading large blocks of data into memory at once. Wrapping a FileInputStream in a BufferedInputStream before passing it to DataInputStream improves efficiency.
In Java, a `char` takes 2 bytes (Unicode). `writeChar` writes the character as a 2-byte value. Writing two characters results in 2 * 2 = 4 bytes.
